$!You may need to tell DVLA if you have had a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) - also known as a 'mini-stroke'.$!

%You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.%

##Car or motorcycle licence

You don't need to tell DVLA.

For more information, download leaflet 'TIA1 - Car or motorcycle drivers who have had a stroke or transient ischaemic attack'.

$D
[Download 'TIA1 - Car or motorcycle drivers who have had a stroke or transient ischaemic attack' (PDF, 260KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_067958.pdf "Download 'TIA1 - Car or motorcycle drivers who have had a stroke or transient ischaemic attack' (PDF, 260KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Bus, coach or lorry licence

You must tell DVLA. Fill in form STR1V and send it to the address on the form.

$D
[Download 'STR1V - Confidential medical information' (PDF, 315KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_201618.pdf "Download medical questionnaire"){:rel="external"}
$D

*[DVLA]: Driver Vehicle and Licensing Agency
*[TIA]: Transient ischaemic attack
overview: You may need to tell DVLA if you've had a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) - download the correct form if you need to let them know
title: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA) and driving
